H0.text: Water having a high specific heat capacity best helps aquatic life survive in lakes during the winter.

H1.text: Waterâ€™s high surface tension is the property that best helps aquatic life survive in lakes during the winter.

H2.text: Water is less dense as a solid than as a liquid, which best helps aquatic life survive in lakes during the winter.

H3.text: Water is a polar molecule, a property that best helps aquatic life survive in lakes during the winter.

A4.text: Because ice is less dense than liquid water, it floats, and this prevents bottom-up freezing of the bodies of water. Instead, a sheltered environment for animal and plant life is formed beneath the floating ice, which protects the underside from short-term weather extremes such as wind chill.
